objects.abstract:
Sum of EMODnet Vessel Density maps for Sailing (4) and Pleasure Craft (5), 2019.

The Vessel Density maps in the EU are created since the 2019 by Cogea for the European Marine Observation and Data Network (EMODnet). The dataset is updated every year and is available for viewing and download on EMODnet Human Activities web portal (https://emodnet.ec.europa.eu/en/human-activities). The maps are based on AIS data yearly purchased from Collecte Localisation Satellites (CLS) and ORBCOMM. The maps, GeoTIFF format, show shipping density in 1x1km cells of a grid covering all EU waters and some neighbouring areas. Density is expressed as hours per square kilometre per month. The following ship types are available:0 Other, 1 Fishing, 2 Service, 3 Dredging or underwater ops, 4 Sailing, 5 Pleasure Craft, 6 High speed craft, 7 Tug and towing, 8 Passenger, 9 Cargo, 10 Tanker, 11 Military and Law Enforcement, 12 Unknown and All ship types. Data are available by month of year. Yearly averages are also available.

objects.abstract:
Restriced areas for wind farm implants provided by CoCoNet.

COCONET identifies groups of putatively interconnected MPAs in the Mediterranean and the Black Seas, shifting from local (single MPA) to regional (Networks of MPAs) and basin (network of networks) scales. The project is meant to enhance policies of effective environmental management, also to ascertain if the existing MPAs are sufficient for ecological networking and to suggest how to design further protection schemes based on effective exchanges between protected areas. The coastal focus is widened to off shore and deep sea habitats, comprising them in MPAs Networks. These activities will also individuate areas where Offshore Wind Farms might become established, avoiding too sensitive habitats but acting as stepping stones through MPAs.

objects.abstract:
This layer visualizes the fishing pressure exerted by the Italian trawl fleet operating in the Strait of Sicily. The data represents the total catch, a measure combining LPUE and fishing duration, for a diverse range of commercially important Elasmobranches by-catch species. These species include Mustelus spp, Raja asteria, Raja clavata, Raja miraletus, Raja oxyrinchus, Scyliorhinus canicula, Squalus blainville. The research was conducted as part of the ABIOMMED project (11.0661/2020/839620/SUB/ENV.C2), utilizing an enhanced version of the SMART model (Russo et al., 2019). The study relied on fishing effort data derived from the Italian trawl fleet's Vessel Monitoring System (VMS) and landing data collected under the EU Data Collection Framework.

Resolution 7x7 km.
objects.name: elasm_extr
objects.title: Elasmobranches Total Landings Italian OTB SoS

objects.abstract:
This layer represents the fishing effort of the Italian fleet utilizing passive gear, including trammel nets, set longlines, pots, and gillnet. The values are normalized on a scale from 0 to 1. The layer was created by integrating (as a sum) two types of data: (a) Local Ecological Knowledge (LEK) and (b) Vessel Monitoring System (VMS) data.

a) Local Ecological Knowledge (LEK):
This component was derived from the study by Grati, F., Azzurro, E., Scanu, M., Tassetti, A. N., Bolognini, L., Guicciardi, S., Scannella, D., ... & Arneri, E. (2022). Mapping smallโscale fisheries through a coordinated participatory strategy. Fish and Fisheries, 23(4), 773-785. The data were collected under the MedSudMed project, and the total fishing effort (expressed as fishing operations per year) for trammel nets, gillnets, traps, and bottom longlines was normalized using the Min-Max normalization method.

b) Vessel Monitoring System (VMS) Data:
This layer was generated using VMS data, calculated as the sum of the fishing effort (Number of hours * Length overall) for the following métiers: Set Longlines (Demersal Fish), Pots and Traps, Trammel Nets, and Gillnets. The data were also normalized using the Min-Max normalization method.
objects.name: SSF_LEK_VMS_dom_UTM
objects.title: Fishing effort SSF  in SoS

objects.abstract: Total AIS fishing effort for all vessels and gear types in italian waters from Global Fishing Watch for 2023
objects.name: public_global_fishing_effort_v20231026
objects.purpose:
Global Fishing Watch uses data about a vessel’s identity, type, location, speed, direction and more that is broadcast using the Automatic Identification System (AIS) and collected via satellites and terrestrial receivers. AIS was developed for safety/collision-avoidance. Global Fishing Watch analyzes AIS data collected from vessels that our research has identified as known or possible commercial fishing vessels, and applies a fishing presence algorithm to determine “apparent fishing activity” based on changes in vessel speed and direction. The algorithm classifies each AIS broadcast data point for these vessels as either apparently fishing or not fishing and shows the former on the Global Fishing Watch fishing activity heat map. AIS data as broadcast may vary in completeness, accuracy and quality. Also, data collection by satellite or terrestrial receivers may introduce errors through missing or inaccurate data. Global Fishing Watch’s fishing presence algorithm is a best effort mathematically to identify “apparent fishing activity.” As a result, it is possible that some fishing activity is not identified as such by Global Fishing Watch; conversely, Global Fishing Watch may show apparent fishing activity where fishing is not actually taking place. For these reasons, Global Fishing Watch qualifies designations of vessel fishing activity, including synonyms of the term “fishing activity,” such as “fishing” or “fishing effort,” as “apparent,” rather than certain. Any/all Global Fishing Watch information about “apparent fishing activity” should be considered an estimate and must be relied upon solely at your own risk. Global Fishing Watch is taking steps to make sure fishing activity designations are as accurate as possible. Global Fishing Watch fishing presence algorithms are developed and tested using actual fishing event data collected by observers, combined with expert analysis of vessel movement data resulting in the manual classification of thousands of known fishing events. Global Fishing Watch also collaborates extensively with academic researchers through our research program to share fishing activity classification data and automated classification techniques.
 
Filters:  timestamp >= '2023-01-01T00:00:00.000Z' and timestamp <= '2024-01-01T00:00:00.000Z'
Resolution: high (100th degree resolution)

Global Fishing Watch’s fishing presence algorithm is a best effort mathematically to identify “apparent fishing activity.” As a result, it is possible that some fishing activity is not identified as such by Global Fishing Watch; conversely, Global Fishing Watch may show apparent fishing activity where fishing is not actually taking place. For these reasons, Global Fishing Watch qualifies designations of vessel fishing activity, including synonyms of the term “fishing activity,” such as “fishing” or “fishing effort,” as “apparent,” rather than certain. Any/all Global Fishing Watch information about “apparent fishing activity” should be considered an estimate and must be relied upon solely at your own risk. Global Fishing Watch is taking steps to make sure fishing activity designations are as accurate as possible. Global Fishing Watch fishing presence algorithms are developed and tested using actual fishing event data collected by observers, combined with expert analysis of vessel movement data resulting in the manual classification of thousands of known fishing events. Global Fishing Watch also collaborates extensively with academic researchers through our research program to share fishing activity classification data and automated classification techniques.

Climatological period: 1987-2000 [from June to november]

Daily SST retrieved by Copernicus Marine Services

  • Sea-bottom temperature – Black Sea 2017, Emodnet Seabed Habitats
  • Bathymetry Black Sea -2016, Emodnet Bathymetry
  • Black Sea Seabed substrates – 2019 – Emodnet Seabed habitats

objects.abstract:
Posidonia oceanica and Cymodocea nodosa habitat suitability maps for 2005-2024 (present), 2045-2064 (Mid-Future, hereafter: Mid-RCP4.5 and Mid-RCP8.5) and 2080-2099 (Far-Future, hereafter Far-RCP4.5 and Far-RCP8.5). 0 = unsuitable, 1 = suitable, NA = out of bathimetric range (0-40m)

 

Submitted manuscript: 

"Climate change impacts Mediterranean seagrass’ associated communities as a consequence of the alteration of seascape structure" by Baldan, Damiano; Cunillera-Montcusí, David; Reale, Marco; Piani, Stefano; Gianni, Fabrizio; Zunino, Serena; Cossarini, Gianpiero; Salon, Stefano ; Solidoro, Cosimo; Bandelj, Vinko,

 

Climate change is dramatically affecting biogenic habitats by altering the
geographic distribution of the foundational species and the structure of
landscapes they form. The associated biotic communities are
experiencing significant changes in connectivity, with cascading effects on
their spatial structure. Frameworks to assess the impacts of climate
change on biotic communities inhabiting biogenic habitats are however
largely missing. In this paper, we focus on two key habitat-forming
species in the Mediterranean Sea: the seagrass Posidonia oceanica and
Cymodocea nodosa, with the aim of assessing the cascading effects of
climate change on their habitats and associated biodiversity. We employ
state-of-the-art physical and biogeochemical data for the Mediterranean
Sea to model the seagrass distribution in the present climate using an
ensemble approach. Based on the identified habitats configuration, we
employ a neutral coalescent model to simulate virtual metacommunities
structured by stochastic demographic processes and dispersal. Our
results show a strong range contraction for both seagrass species, a
decrease in alpha diversity of associated communities, and an increase in
beta diversity at the Mediterranean scale. Such changes are solely the
result of the rearrangement of the landscape caused by climate change
and create an offset for any distributional change of the simulated
communities related to niche effects. At the local scale, we show that
patterns of alpha diversity under realistic species dispersal are strongly
correlated with habitat availability, while beta diversity is largely
influenced by the changes in the spatial configuration of seagrass
habitats. By highlighting hotspots of metacommunity change linked to
habitat fragmentation, our method can be useful for planning
conservation and restoration measures at local and regional scales

objects.abstract:
This layer represents the Essential Fish Habitats (EFH) (nursery) of multiple species. Each cell indicates the number of species that present a nursery area consistently over the years, with a persistence index of 60%, which means at least 60% of the years within the entire time series show a nursery hotspot in that location.

The species considered are as follows:

  • European Hake (Merluccius merluccius, HKE)
  • Deep-Water Rose Shrimp (Parapenaeus longirostris, DPS)
  • Norway Lobster (Nephrops norvegicus, NEP)
  • Broadtail Shortfin Squid (Illex coindetii, SQM)
  • Blackmouth Catshark (Galeus melastomus, SHO)
  • Giant Red Shrimp (Aristaeomorpha foliacea, ARS)
  • Thornback Ray (Raja clavata, RJC)

objects.abstract:
Passenger - Annual average 2019.

The Vessel Density maps in the EU are created since the 2019 by Cogea for the European Marine Observation and Data Network (EMODnet). The dataset is updated every year and is available for viewing and download on EMODnet Human Activities web portal (https://emodnet.ec.europa.eu/en/human-activities). The maps are based on AIS data yearly purchased from Collecte Localisation Satellites (CLS) and ORBCOMM. The maps, GeoTIFF format, show shipping density in 1x1km cells of a grid covering all EU waters and some neighbouring areas. Density is expressed as hours per square kilometre per month. The following ship types are available:0 Other, 1 Fishing, 2 Service, 3 Dredging or underwater ops, 4 Sailing, 5 Pleasure Craft, 6 High speed craft, 7 Tug and towing, 8 Passenger, 9 Cargo, 10 Tanker, 11 Military and Law Enforcement, 12 Unknown and All ship types. Data are available by month of year. Yearly averages are also available.
objects.name: wid6_passenger_all_europe_yearly_20190101000000_20191231235959_tdm_grid
objects.title: Passenger - Vessel density map - EMODnet Human Activities (2019)

objects.name: a__2019_st_05_avg
objects.title: Pleasure craft - Vessel density EMODnet (2019)

objects.abstract:
This layer visualizes the pockmark fields in the Northern Sector of the Strait of Sicily. Pockmarks are topographic depressions that form in areas of fluid discharge and require fine-grained sediments to develop and maintain their structure over extended periods. These pockmark fields may serve as significant hotspots of microbial biodiversity, regulated by the intensity of methane flux, which supports a rich chemosymbiotic life (Taviani, M., 2014).

The information presented here was gathered from several scientific sources, including Spatola et al. 2018a & b, Volpi et al. 2022, Taviani et al. 2013, Micallef et al. 2022, and Prior 2005. Specifically, Spatola et al. (2018a & b) and Volpi et al. (2022) provided the geographical coordinates for the center of each pockmark. The fields were then digitized by applying a buffer of 300 meters around the maximum radius.

For the data obtained from Taviani et al. (2013), Micallef et al. (2022), and Prior (2005), the polygons representing the pockmark fields were digitized based on images extracted from the publications, following georeferencing procedures.

objects.title: Pockmark fields SoS

objects.abstract:
Posidonia oceanica and Cymodocea nodosa habitat suitability maps for 2005-2024 (present), 2045-2064 (Mid-Future, hereafter: Mid-RCP4.5 and Mid-RCP8.5) and 2080-2099 (Far-Future, hereafter Far-RCP4.5 and Far-RCP8.5). 0 = unsuitable, 1 = suitable, NA = out of bathimetric range (0-40m)

 

Submitted manuscript: 

"Climate change impacts Mediterranean seagrass’ associated communities as a consequence of the alteration of seascape structure" by Baldan, Damiano; Cunillera-Montcusí, David; Reale, Marco; Piani, Stefano; Gianni, Fabrizio; Zunino, Serena; Cossarini, Gianpiero; Salon, Stefano ; Solidoro, Cosimo; Bandelj, Vinko,

 

Climate change is dramatically affecting biogenic habitats by altering the
geographic distribution of the foundational species and the structure of
landscapes they form. The associated biotic communities are
experiencing significant changes in connectivity, with cascading effects on
their spatial structure. Frameworks to assess the impacts of climate
change on biotic communities inhabiting biogenic habitats are however
largely missing. In this paper, we focus on two key habitat-forming
species in the Mediterranean Sea: the seagrass Posidonia oceanica and
Cymodocea nodosa, with the aim of assessing the cascading effects of
climate change on their habitats and associated biodiversity. We employ
state-of-the-art physical and biogeochemical data for the Mediterranean
Sea to model the seagrass distribution in the present climate using an
ensemble approach. Based on the identified habitats configuration, we
employ a neutral coalescent model to simulate virtual metacommunities
structured by stochastic demographic processes and dispersal. Our
results show a strong range contraction for both seagrass species, a
decrease in alpha diversity of associated communities, and an increase in
beta diversity at the Mediterranean scale. Such changes are solely the
result of the rearrangement of the landscape caused by climate change
and create an offset for any distributional change of the simulated
communities related to niche effects. At the local scale, we show that
patterns of alpha diversity under realistic species dispersal are strongly
correlated with habitat availability, while beta diversity is largely
influenced by the changes in the spatial configuration of seagrass
habitats. By highlighting hotspots of metacommunity change linked to
habitat fragmentation, our method can be useful for planning
conservation and restoration measures at local and regional scales

objects.abstract:
This layer represents the Essential Fish Habitats (EFH) for spawning multiple species. Each cell indicates the number of species that consistently exhibit spawning activity over the years, with a persistence index of 60%, which means at least 60% of the years within the entire time series show a spawning hotspot in that location.

The species considered are as follows:

  • Giant Red Shrimp (Aristaeomorpha foliacea, ARS) 
  • Blue and Red Shrimp (Aristeus antennatus, ARA)
  • Blackmouth Catshark (Galeus melastomus, SHO) 
  • Broadtail Shortfin Squid (Illex coindetii, SQM) 
  • European Hake (Merluccius merluccius, HKE) 
  • Surmullet (Mullus surmuletus, MUR) 
  • Norway Lobster (Nephrops norvegicus, NEP) 
  • Blackspot Seabream (Pagellus erythrinus, PAC) 
  • Deep-Water Rose Shrimp (Parapenaeus longirostris, DPS)
  • Thornback Ray (Raja clavata, RJC)

objects.abstract:
Plastics dispersion model (HCMR)
A 3-D coupled hydrodynamic/Lagrangian particle drift model is developed to simulate the dispersion of plastics originated from land-based sources (cities and rivers) in the Black Sea, previously described in Deliverable 2.1. The model is continuously being developed and evaluated. In this context, the adopted sources of plastic have been updated as compared to Deliverable 2.1, and are summarized below:
•    Input of micro- and macro-plastics from river discharge from Lebreton et al. (2017). The predicted loads of plastic from Lebreton et al. (2017) were evaluated via comparison with field data (Lechner et al.,2014; van der Wal et al. 2015) and the Upper mass input estimate was adopted as it better fit with the observations (~ 1000 tonnes/year).
•    Input of macroplastics (> 2.5 cm) from rivers discharge from Gonzalez et al. (2021).
•    Input of macroplastics from coastal populations, considering the population within a buffer of 30 km from the Black Sea coastline (GIS data: 250m resolution; JRC, European Commission,2015). Macroplastics load was the country-specific mismanaged plastic production (kg/inh/day) from Jambeck et al. (2015), multiplied by a delivery ratio of 0.003 previously adopted by Schimt et al. (2017).
•    Microplastics input through treated (TD) and untreated (UD) wastewater is considered based on the global dataset of Jones et al. (2020) for wastewater production. The daily microplastics load was calculated based on Tsiaras et al. (2021) as follows: Microplastics load (particles/day) = UM * (TD*R+UD) with UM (17500 #/m3) being the adopted microplastics concentration in untreated water, and R, the removal efficiency of wastewater treatment.  In the absence of any coherent information about the type of treatment applied in wastewater treatment plants of the Black Sea, a primary treatment was assumed for all coastal populations, with a removal efficiency of 25% (Tsiaras et al. 2021).
Finally, the considered types/sizes of macroplastics have been changed (5 mm–2.5 cm, 2.5–10 cm, 10 -50 cm bottles, 10 -50 cm bags, 10 -50 cm foam, and other particles of 10-50 cm) to allow direct comparison with available data of floating litter in the Black Sea (Gonzalez et al., 2022).
objects.name: macro
objects.title: Surface macroplastics distribution in the Black Sea - Plastics dispersion model (HCMR)

objects.abstract:
Tanker - Annual average 2019.

The Vessel Density maps in the EU are created since the 2019 by Cogea for the European Marine Observation and Data Network (EMODnet). The dataset is updated every year and is available for viewing and download on EMODnet Human Activities web portal (https://emodnet.ec.europa.eu/en/human-activities). The maps are based on AIS data yearly purchased from Collecte Localisation Satellites (CLS) and ORBCOMM. The maps, GeoTIFF format, show shipping density in 1x1km cells of a grid covering all EU waters and some neighbouring areas. Density is expressed as hours per square kilometre per month. The following ship types are available:0 Other, 1 Fishing, 2 Service, 3 Dredging or underwater ops, 4 Sailing, 5 Pleasure Craft, 6 High speed craft, 7 Tug and towing, 8 Passenger, 9 Cargo, 10 Tanker, 11 Military and Law Enforcement, 12 Unknown and All ship types. Data are available by month of year. Yearly averages are also available.

objects.title: Test layer for CEREMA

objects.abstract: This layer visualizes the fishing pressure exerted by the Italian trawl fleet operating in the Strait of Sicily. The data represents the total catch, a measure combining weight, fishing duration, and vessel length, for a diverse range of commercially important species. These species include Merluccius merluccius, Mullus barbatus, Mullus surmuletus, Lophius piscatorius, Boops boops, Trachurus trachurus, Illex coindetii, Eledone cirrhosa, Eledone moschata, Octopus vulgaris, Sepia officinalis, Squilla mantis, Parapenaeus longirostris, Aristeus antennatus, Aristaeomorpha foliacea, Nephrops norvegicus. The research was conducted as part of the ABIOMMED project (11.0661/2020/839620/SUB/ENV.C2), utilizing an enhanced version of the SMART model (Russo et al., 2019). The study relied on fishing effort data derived from the Italian trawl fleet's Vessel Monitoring System (VMS) and landing data collected under the EU Data Collection Framework.
objects.name: OTB_Tot_Landings_UTM
objects.title: Total Landings Italian OTB SoS

objects.abstract: The layer represents a proxy of nautical tourism (boating/yachting) in the area. It was developed based on the location of marinas and the number of boats, assuming that the density and distribution of tourist ports can be considered a proxy of the intensity of recreational boating activities. The layer was generated within the framework of the MSP4BIODIVERSITY project.

objects.abstract:
Tankers - annual average 2022.

The Vessel Density maps in the EU are created since the 2019 by Cogea for the European Marine Observation and Data Network (EMODnet). The dataset is updated every year and is available for viewing and download on EMODnet Human Activities web portal (https://emodnet.ec.europa.eu/en/human-activities). The maps are based on AIS data yearly purchased from Collecte Localisation Satellites (CLS) and ORBCOMM. The maps, GeoTIFF format, show shipping density in 1x1km cells of a grid covering all EU waters and some neighbouring areas. Density is expressed as hours per square kilometre per month. The following ship types are available:0 Other, 1 Fishing, 2 Service, 3 Dredging or underwater ops, 4 Sailing, 5 Pleasure Craft, 6 High speed craft, 7 Tug and towing, 8 Passenger, 9 Cargo, 10 Tanker, 11 Military and Law Enforcement, 12 Unknown and All ship types. Data are available by month of year. Yearly averages are also available.
